Abstract

We provide new and tight lower bounds on the ability of players to implement equilibria using cheap talk, that is, just allowing communication among the players. One of our main results is that, in general, it is impossible to implement three-player Nash equilibria in a bounded number of rounds. We also give the first rigorous connection between Byzantine agreement lower bounds and lower bounds on implementation. To this end we consider a number of variants of Byzantine agreement and introduce reduction arguments. We also give lower bounds on the running time of two player implementations. All our results extended to lower bounds on (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibria, a solution concept that tolerates deviations by coalitions of size up to kğ‘˜k and deviations by up to tğ‘¡t players with unknown utilities (who may be malicious).

1 Introduction

The question of whether a problem in a multiagent system that can be solved with a trusted mediator can be solved by just the agents in the system, without the mediator, has attracted a great deal of attention in both computer science (particularly in the cryptography community) and game theory. In cryptography, the focus on the problem has been on secure multiparty computation. Here it is assumed that each agent iğ‘–i has some private information xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}. Fix functions f1,â€¦,fnsubscriptğ‘“1â€¦subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{1},\ldots,f_{n}. The goal is have agent iğ‘–i learn fiâ€‹(x1,â€¦,xn)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›f_{i}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}) without learning anything about xjsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x_{j} for jâ‰ iğ‘—ğ‘–j\neq i beyond what is revealed by the value of fiâ€‹(x1,â€¦,xn)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›f_{i}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}). With a trusted mediator, this is trivial: each agent iğ‘–i just gives the mediator its private value xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}; the mediator then sends each agent iğ‘–i the value fiâ€‹(x1,â€¦,xn)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›f_{i}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}). Work on multiparty computation (see [Gol04] for a survey) provides conditions under which this can be done. In game theory, the focus has been on whether an equilibrium in a game with a mediator can be implemented using what is called cheap talkâ€”that is, just by players communicating among themselves (see [Mye97] for a survey).

There is a great deal of overlap between the problems studied in computer science and game theory. But there are some significant differences. Perhaps the most significant difference is that, in the computer science literature, the interest has been in doing multiparty computation in the presence of possibly malicious adversaries, who do everything they can to subvert the computation. On the other hand, in the game theory literature, the assumption is that players have preference and seek to maximize their utility; thus, they will subvert the computation iff it is in their best interests to do so. Following [ADGH06], we consider here both rational adversaries, who try to maximize their utility, and possibly malicious adversaries (who can also be considered rational adversaries whose utilities we do not understand).

1.1 Our Results

In this paper we provide new and optimal lower bounds on the ability to implement mediators with cheap talk. Recall that a Nash equilibrium Ïƒğœ\sigma is a tuple of strategies such that given that all other players play their corresponding part of Ïƒğœ\sigma then the best response is also to play Ïƒğœ\sigma. Given a Nash equilibrium Ïƒğœ\sigma we say that a strategy profile ÏğœŒ\rho is a kğ‘˜k-punishment strategy for Ïƒğœ\sigma if, when all but kğ‘˜k players play their component of ÏğœŒ\rho, then no matter what the remaining kğ‘˜k players do, their payoff is strictly less than what it is with Ïƒğœ\sigma. We now describe some highlights of our results in the two simplest settings: (1) where rational players cannot form coalitions and there are no malicious players (this gives us the solution concept of Nash equilibrium) and (2) where there is at most one malicious player. We describe our results in a more general setting in SectionÂ 1.2.

No bounded implementations:

In [ADGH06] it was shown that any Nash equilibrium with a mediator for three-player games with a 1-punishment strategy can be implemented using cheap talk. The expected running time of the implementation is constant. It is natural to ask if implementations with a bounded number of rounds exist for all three-player games. TheoremÂ 2 shows this is not the case, implementations must have infinite executions and cannot be bounded for all three-player games. This lower bound highlights the importance of using randomization. An earlier attempt to provide a three-player cheap talk implementation [Ben03] uses a bounded implementation, and hence cannot work in general. The key insight of the lower bound is that when the implementation is bounded, then at some point the punishment strategy must become ineffective. The details turn out to be quite subtle. The only other lower bound that we are aware of that has the same flavor is the celebrated FLP resultÂ [FLP85] for reaching agreement in asynchronous systems, which also shows that no bounded implementation exists. However, we use quite different proof techniques than FLP.

Byzantine Agreement and Game Theory:

We give the first rigorous connection between Byzantine agreement lower bounds and lower bounds on implementation. To get the lower bounds, we need to consider a number of variants of Byzantine agreement, some novel. The novel variants require new impossibility results. We have four results of this flavor:

  1. 1.

    BaranyÂ [Bar92] gives an example to show that, in general, to implement an equilibrium with a mediator in a three-player game, it is necessary to have a 1-punishment strategy. Using the power of randomized Byzantine agreement lower bounds we strengthen his result and show in TheoremÂ 4 that we cannot even get an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implementation in this setting.

  2. 2.

    Using the techniques of [BGW88] or [For90], it is easy to show that any four-player game Nash equilibrium with a mediator can be implemented using cheap talk even if no 1-punishment strategy exists. Moreover, these implementations are universal; they do not depend on the playersâ€™ utilities. In TheoremÂ 3 we prove that universal implementations do not exist in general for three-player games. Our proof uses a nontrivial reduction to the weak Byzantine agreement (WBA) problemÂ [Lam83]. To obtain our lower bound, we need to prove a new impossibility result for WBA, namely, that no protocol with a finite expected running time can solve WBA.

  3. 3.

    In [ADGH06] we show that for six-player games with a 2-punishment strategy, any Nash equilibrium can be implemented even in the presence of at most one malicious player. In TheoremÂ 5 we show that for five players even Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“-implementation is impossible. The proof uses a variant of Byzantine agreement; this is related to the problem of broadcast with extended consistency introduced by FitziÂ et al.Â [FHHW03]. Our reduction maps the rational player to a Byzantine process that is afraid of being detected and the malicious player to a standard Byzantine process.

  4. 4.

    In TheoremÂ 8, we show that for four-player games with at most one malicious player, to implement the mediator, we must have a PKI setup in place, even if the players are all computationally bounded and even if we are willing to settle for Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“implementations. Our lower bound is based on a reduction to a novel relaxation of the Byzantine agreement problem.

Bounds on running time:

We provide bounds on the number of rounds needed to implement two-player games. In TheoremÂ 9(a) we prove that the expected running time of any implementation of a two-player mediator equilibrium must depend on the utilities of the game, even if there is a 1-punishment strategy. This is in contrast to the three-player case, where the expected running time is constant. In TheoremÂ 9(b) we prove that the expected running time of any Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“implementation of a two-player mediator equilibrium for which there is no 1-punishment strategy must depend on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Both results are obtained using a new two-player variant of the secret-sharing game. The only result that we are aware of that has a similar sprit is that of Boneh and NaorÂ [BN00], where it is shown that two-party protocols with â€œbounded unfairnessâ€ of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon must have running time that depends on the value of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. The implementations given by Urbano and Vila [UV02, UV04] in the two-player case are independent of the utilities; the above results show that their implementation cannot be correct in general.

1.2 Our results for implementing robust and resistent mediators

In [ADGH06] (ADGH from now on), we argued that it is important to consider deviations by both rational players, who have preferences and try to maximize them, and players that can be viewed as malicious, although it is perhaps better to think of them as rational players whose utilities are not known by the other players or mechanism designer. We considered equilibria that are (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust; roughly speaking, this means that the equilibrium tolerates deviations by up to kğ‘˜k rational players, whose utilities are presumed known, and up to tğ‘¡t players with unknown utilities (i.e., possibly malicious players). We showed how (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibria with mediators could be implemented using cheap talk, by first showing that, under appropriate assumptions, we could implement secret sharing in a (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust way using cheap talk. These assumptions involve standard considerations in the game theory and distributed systems literature, specifically, (a) the relationship between kğ‘˜k, tğ‘¡t and nğ‘›n, the total number of players in the system; (b) whether players know the exact utilities of other players; (c) whether there are broadcast channels or just point-to-point channels; (d) whether cryptography is available; and (e) whether the game has a (k+t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k+t)-punishment strategy; that is, a strategy that, if used by all but at most k+tğ‘˜ğ‘¡k+t players, guarantees that every player gets a worse outcome than they do with the equilibrium strategy. Here we provide a complete picture of when implementation is possible, providing lower bounds that match the known upper bounds (or improvements of them that we have obtained). The following is a high-level picture of the results. (The results discussed in SectionÂ 1.1 are special cases of the results stated below. Note that all the upper bounds mentioned here are either in ADGH, slight improvements of results in ADGH, or are known in the literature; see SectionÂ 3 for the details. The new results claimed in the current submission are the matching lower bounds.)

  • â€¢

    If oâ€‹n>3â€‹k+3â€‹tğ‘œğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡on>3k+3t, then mediators can be implemented using cheap talk; no punishment strategy is required, no knowledge of other agentsâ€™ utilities is required, and the cheap-talk strategy has bounded running time that does not depend on the utilities (TheoremÂ 1(a) in SectionÂ 3).

  • â€¢

    If nâ‰¤3â€‹k+3â€‹tğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n\leq 3k+3t, then we cannot, in general, implement a mediator using cheap talk without knowledge of other agentsâ€™ utilities (TheoremÂ 3). Moreover, even if other agentsâ€™ utilities are known, we cannot, in general, implement a mediator without having a punishment strategy (TheoremÂ 4) nor with bounded running time (TheoremÂ 2).

  • â€¢

    If n>2â€‹k+3â€‹tğ‘›2ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n>2k+3t, then mediators can be implemented using cheap talk if there is a punishment strategy (and utilities are known) in finite expected running time that does not depend on the utilities (TheoremÂ 1(b) in SectionÂ 3).

  • â€¢

    If nâ‰¤2â€‹k+3â€‹tğ‘›2ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n\leq 2k+3t, then we cannot, in general, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk, even if there is a punishment strategy and utilities are known (TheoremÂ 5).

  • â€¢

    If n>2â€‹k+2â€‹tğ‘›2ğ‘˜2ğ‘¡n>2k+2t and we can simulate broadcast then, for all Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, we can Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk, with bounded expected running time that does not depend on the utilities in the game or on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon (TheoremÂ 1(c) in SectionÂ 3). (Intuitively, an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implementation is an implementation where a player can gain at most Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon by deviating.)

  • â€¢

    If nâ‰¤2â€‹k+2â€‹tğ‘›2ğ‘˜2ğ‘¡n\leq 2k+2t, we cannot, in general, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk even if we have broadcast channels (TheoremÂ 7). Moreover, even if we assume cryptography and broadcast channels, we cannot, in general, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk with expected running time that does not depend on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon (TheoremÂ 9(b)); even if there is a punishment strategy, then we still cannot, in general, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk with expected running time independent of the utilities in the game (TheoremÂ 9(a)).

  • â€¢

    If n>k+3â€‹tğ‘›ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n>k+3t then, assuming cryptography, we can Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk; moreover, if there is a punishment strategy, the expected running time does not depend on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon (TheoremÂ 1(e) in SectionÂ 3).

  • â€¢

    If nâ‰¤k+3â€‹tğ‘›ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n\leq k+3t, then even assuming cryptography, we cannot, in general, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implement a mediator using cheap talk (TheoremÂ 8).

  • â€¢

    If n>k+tğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘¡n>k+t, then assuming cryptography and that a PKI (Public Key Infrastructure) is in place,111We can replace the assumption of a PKI here and elsewhere by the assumption that there is a trusted preprocessing phase where players may broadcast. we can Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implement a mediator (TheoremÂ 1(d) in SectionÂ 3); moreover, if there is a punishment strategy, the expected running time does not depend on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon (TheoremÂ 1(e) in SectionÂ 3).

The lower bounds are existential results; they show that if certain conditions do not hold, then there exists an equilibrium that can be implemented by a mediator that cannot be implemented using cheap talk. There are other games where these conditions do not hold but we can nevertheless implement a mediator.

1.3 Related work

There has been a great deal of work on implementing mediators, both in computer science and game theory. The results above generalize a number of results that appear in the literature. We briefly discuss the most relevant work on implementing mediators here. Other work related to this paper is discussed where it is relevant.

In game theory, the study of implementing mediators using cheap talk goes back to Crawford and Sobel [CS82]. Barany [Bar92] shows that if nâ‰¥4ğ‘›4n\geq 4, k=1ğ‘˜1k=1, and t=0ğ‘¡0t=0 (i.e., the setting for Nash equilibrium), a mediator can be implemented in a game where players do not have private information. Forges [For90] provides what she calls a universal mechanism for implementing mediators; essentially, when combining her results with those of Barany, we get the special case of TheoremÂ 1(a) where k=1ğ‘˜1k=1 and t=0ğ‘¡0t=0. Ben-Porath [Ben03] considers implementing a mediator with cheap talk in the case that k=1ğ‘˜1k=1 if nâ‰¥3ğ‘›3n\geq 3 and there is a 1-punishment strategy. He seems to have been the first to consider punishment strategies (although his notion is different from ours: he requires that there be an equilibrium that is dominated by the equilibrium that we are trying to implement). Heller [Hel05] extends Ben-Porathâ€™s result to allow arbitrary kğ‘˜k. TheoremÂ 1(b) generalizes Ben-Porath and Hellerâ€™s results. Although TheoremÂ 1(b) shows that the statement of Ben-Porathâ€™s result is correct, Ben-Porathâ€™s implementation takes a bounded number of rounds; TheoremÂ 2 shows it cannot be correct.222Although Hellerâ€™s implementation does not take a bounded number of rounds, it suffers from problems similar to those of Ben-Porath. Heller proves a matching lower bound; TheoremÂ 5 generalizes Hellerâ€™s lower bound to the case that t>0ğ‘¡0t>0. (This turns out to require a much more complicated game than that considered by Heller.) Urbano and Vila [UV02, UV04] use cryptography to deal with the case that n=2ğ‘›2n=2 and k=1ğ‘˜1k=1;333However, they make somewhat vague and nonstandard assumptions about the cryptographic tools they use. TheoremÂ 1(e)) generalizes their result to arbitrary kğ‘˜k and tğ‘¡t. However, just as with Ben-Porath, Urbano and Vilaâ€™s implementation takes a bounded number of rounds; As we said in SectionÂ 1.1, TheoremÂ 9(a) shows that it cannot be correct.

In the cryptography community, results on implementing mediators go back to 1982 (although this terminology was not used), in the context of (secure) multiparty computation. Since there are no utilities in this problem, the focus has been on essentially what we call here tğ‘¡t-immunity: no group of tğ‘¡t players can prevent the remaining players from learning the function value, nor can they learn the other playersâ€™ private values. Results of Yao [Yao82] can be viewed as showing that if n=2ğ‘›2n=2 and appropriate computational hardness assumptions are made, then, for all Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, we can obtain 111-immunity with probability greater than 1âˆ’Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1-\epsilon if appropriate computational hardness assumptions hold. Goldreich, Micali, and Wigderson [GMW87] extend Yaoâ€™s result to the case that t>0ğ‘¡0t>0 and n>tğ‘›ğ‘¡n>t. Ben-Or, Goldwasser, and Wigderson [BGW88] and Chaum, CrÃ©peau, and Damgard [CCD88] show that, without computational hardness assumptions, we can get tğ‘¡t-immunity if n>3â€‹tğ‘›3ğ‘¡n>3t; moreover, the protocol of Ben-Or, Goldwasser, and Wigderson does not need an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon â€œerrorâ€ term. Although they did not consider utilities, their protocol actually gives a (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust implementation of a mediator using cheap talk if n>3â€‹k+3â€‹tğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n>3k+3t; that is, they essentially prove TheoremÂ 1(a). (Thus, although these results predate those of Barany and Forges, they are actually stronger.) Rabin and Ben-Or [RB89] provide a tğ‘¡t-immune implementation of a mediator with â€œerrorâ€ Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon if broadcast can be simulated. Again, when we add utilities, their protocol actually gives an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“(k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust implementation. Thus, they essentially prove TheoremÂ 1(c). Dodis, Halevi, and Rabin [DHR00] seem to have been the first to apply cryptographic techniques to game-theoretic solution concepts; they consider the case that n=2ğ‘›2n=2 and k=1ğ‘˜1k=1 and there is no private information (in which case the equilibrium in the mediator game is a correlated equilibrium [Aum87]); their result is essentially that of Urbano and Vila [UV04] (although their protocol does not suffer form the problems of that of Urbano and Vila).

Halpern and Teague [HT04] were perhaps the first to consider the general problem of multiparty computation with rational players. In this setting, they essentially prove TheoremÂ 1(d) for the case that t=0ğ‘¡0t=0 and nâ‰¥3ğ‘›3n\geq 3. However, their focus is on the solution concept of iterated deletion. They show that there is no Nash equilibrium for rational multiparty computation with rational agents that survives iterated deletion and give a protocol with finite expected running time that does survive iterated deletion. If nâ‰¤3â€‹(k+t)ğ‘›3ğ‘˜ğ‘¡n\leq 3(k+t), it follows easily from TheoremÂ 2: that there is no multiparty computation protocol that is a Nash equilibrium, we do not have to require that the protocol survive iterated deletion to get the result if nâ‰¤3â€‹(k+t)ğ‘›3ğ‘˜ğ‘¡n\leq 3(k+t). Various generalizations of the Halpern and Teague results have been proved. We have already mentioned the work of ADGH. Lysanskaya and Triandopoulos [LT06] independently proved the special case of TheoremÂ 1(c) where k=1ğ‘˜1k=1 and t+1<n/2ğ‘¡1ğ‘›2t+1<n/2 (they also consider survival of iterated deletion); Gordon and Katz [GK06] independently proved a special case of TheoremÂ 1(d) where k=1ğ‘˜1k=1, t=0ğ‘¡0t=0, and nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2.

In this paper we are interested in implementing equilibrium by using standard communication channels. An alternate option is to consider the possibility of simulating equilibrium by using much stronger primitives. Izmalkov, Micali, and Lepinski [IML05] show that, if there is a punishment strategy and we have available strong primitives that they call envelopes and ballot boxes, we can implement arbitrary mediators perfectly (without an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon error) in the case that k=1ğ‘˜1k=1, in the sense that every equilibrium of the game with the mediator corresponds to an equilibrium of the cheap-talk game, and vice versa. In [LMPS04, LMS05], these primitives are also used to obtain implementation that is perfectly collusion proof in the model where, in the game with the mediator, coalitions cannot communicate. (By way of contrast, we allow coalitions to communicate.) Unfortunately, envelopes and ballot boxes cannot be implemented under standard computational and systems assumptions [LMS05].

It is reasonable to ask at this point whether mediators are of practical interest. After all, if three companies negotiate, they can just hire an arguably trusted mediator, say an auditing firm. The disadvantage of this approach in a setting like the internet, with constantly shifting alliances, there are always different groups that want to collaborate; a group may not have the time and flexibility of hiring a mediator, even assuming they can find one they trust. Another concern is that our results simply shift the role of what has to be trust elsewhere. It is certainly true that our results assume point-to-point communication that cannot be intercepted. If nâ‰¤k+3â€‹tğ‘›ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n\leq k+3t, then we must also assume the existence of a public-key infrastructure. Thus, we have essentially shifted from trusting the mediator to trusting the PKI. In practice, individuals who want to collaborate may find point-to-point communication and a PKI more trustworthy than an intermediary, and easier to work with.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In SectionÂ 2, we review the relevant definitions. In SectionÂ 3, we briefly discuss the upper bounds, and compare them to the results of ADGH. In SectionÂ 4, we prove the lower bounds. The missing proofs appear in the appendix.

2 Definitions

In this section, we give detailed definitions of the main notions needed for our results. Sometimes there are subtle differences between our differences and those used in the game-theory literature. We discuss these differences carefully.

2.1 Mediators and cheap talk

We are interested in implementing mediators. Formally, this means we need to consider three games: an underlying game Î“Î“\Gamma, an extension Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} of Î“Î“\Gamma with a mediator, and a cheap-talk extension Î“ctsubscriptÎ“ct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} of Î“Î“\Gamma. Our underlying games are (normal-form) Bayesian games. These are games of incomplete information, where players make only one move, and these moves are made simultaneously. The â€œincomplete informationâ€ is captured by assuming that nature makes the first move and chooses for each player iğ‘–i a type in some set ğ’¯isubscriptğ’¯ğ‘–{\cal T}_{i}, according to some distribution that is commonly known. Formally, a Bayesian game Î“Î“\Gamma is defined by a tuple (N,ğ’¯,A,u,Î¼)ğ‘ğ’¯ğ´ğ‘¢ğœ‡(N,\mathcal{T},A,u,\mu), where Nğ‘N is the set of players, ğ’¯=Ã—iâˆˆNğ’¯i{\cal T}=\times_{i\in N}{\cal T}_{i} is the set of possible types, Î¼ğœ‡\mu is the distribution on types, A=Ã—iâˆˆNAiA=\times_{i\in N}A_{i} is the set of action profiles, and ui:ğ’¯Ã—A:subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ’¯ğ´u_{i}:{\cal T}\times A is the utility of player iğ‘–i as a function of the types prescribed by nature and the actions taken by all players.

A strategy for player iğ‘–i in a Bayesian game Î“Î“\Gamma is a function from iğ‘–iâ€™s type to an action in Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i}; in a game with a mediator, a strategy is a function from iğ‘–iâ€™s type and message history to an action. We allow behavior strategies (i.e., randomized strategies); such a strategy gets an extra argument, which is a sequence of coin flips (intuitively, what a player does can depend on its type, the messages it has sent and received if we are considering games with mediators, and the outcome of some coin flips). We use lower-case Greek letters such as Ïƒğœ\sigma, Ï„ğœ\tau, and ÏğœŒ\rho to denote a strategy profile; Ïƒisubscriptğœğ‘–\sigma_{i} denotes the strategy of player iğ‘–i in strategy profile Ïƒğœ\sigma; if KâŠ†Nğ¾ğ‘K\subseteq N, then ÏƒKsubscriptğœğ¾\sigma_{K} denotes the strategies of the players in Kğ¾K and Ïƒâˆ’Ksubscriptğœğ¾\sigma_{-K} denotes the strategies of the players not in Kğ¾K. Given a strategy profile Ïƒğœ\sigma a player iâˆˆNğ‘–ğ‘i\in N and a type tiâˆˆTisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–t_{i}\in T_{i} let uiâ€‹(ti,Ïƒ)subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–ğœu_{i}(t_{i},\sigma) be the expected utility of player iğ‘–i given that his type is tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i} and each player jâˆˆNğ‘—ğ‘j\in N is playing the strategy Ïƒjsubscriptğœğ‘—\sigma_{j}.

Given an underlying Bayesian game Î“Î“\Gamma as above, a game Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dğ‘‘d that extends Î“Î“\Gamma is, informally, a game where players can communicate with the mediator and then perform an action from Î“Î“\Gamma. The utility function of a player iğ‘–i in Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} is the same as that in Î“Î“\Gamma; thus, the utility of a player iğ‘–i in Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} depends just on the types of all players and the actions taken by all players. Formally, we view both the mediator and the players as interacting Turing machines with access to an unbiased coin (which thus allows them to choose uniformly at random from a finite set of any size). The mediator and players interact for some (possibly unbounded) number of stages. A mediator is characterized by a function ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} that maps the inputs it has received up to a stage (and possible some random bits) to an output for each player. Given an underlying Bayesian game Î“Î“\Gamma where player iğ‘–iâ€™s actions come from the set Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} and a mediator dğ‘‘d, the interaction with the mediator in Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} proceeds in stages, where each stage consists of three phases. In the first phase of a stage, each player iğ‘–i sends an input to dğ‘‘d (player iğ‘–i can send the empty input, i.e., no input at all); in the second phase, dğ‘‘d sends each player iğ‘–i an output according to ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}, (again, the mediator can send the empty output); and in the third phase, each player iğ‘–i chooses an action in Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} or no action at all. A player can play at most one action from Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} in each execution (play) of Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d}. Player iğ‘–iâ€™s utility function in Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} is the same as that in the underlying game Î“Î“\Gamma, and depends only on the action profile in Ağ´A played by the players and the types. To make this precise, we need to define what move an action in Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} is played by player iğ‘–i in executions of Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} where iğ‘–i in fact never plays an action in Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i}. For ease of exposition, we assume that for each player iğ‘–i, some default action aiâˆ—âˆˆAsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ´a_{i}^{*}\in A is chosen. There are other ways of dealing with this issue (see, for example, [AH03] for an alternative approach). Our results do not depend on the choice, since in our upper bounds, with probability 1, all players do play an action in equilibrium, and our impossibility results are independent of the action chosen if players do not choose an action. (We remark that the question of what happens after an infinite execution of the cheap-talk game becomes much more significant in asynchronous systems; see [ADH].)

Although we think of a cheap-talk game as a game where players can communicate with each other (using point-to-point communication and possibly broadcast), formally, it is a game with a special kind of mediator: player iğ‘–i send the mediator whatever messages it wants to send other players in the first phase of a round; the mediator forwards these messages to the intended recipients in the second phase. We can model broadcast messages by just having the mediator tag a message as a broadcast (and sending the same message to all the intended recipients, of course).

We assume that cheap talk games are always unbounded; players are allowed to talk forever. The running time of an execution of a joint strategy Ïƒğœ\sigma is the number of steps taken until the last player makes a move in the underlying game. The running time may be infinite.

It is standard in the game theory literature to view cheap talk as pre-play communication. Thus, although different plays of Î“ctsubscriptÎ“ct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} may have different running times (possibly depending on random factors), it is assumed that it is commonly known when the cheap-talk phase ends; then all players make their decisions simultaneously. It is not possible for some players to continue communicating after some other players have decided (see, for example, [Hel05], where this assumption is explicit). For their possibility results, ADGH define games and give recommended strategies for these games such that, as long as players use the recommended strategy, all players make a move at the same time in each play of the cheap-talk game. However, it is not assumed that this is the case off the equilibrium path (that is, if players do not follow the recommended strategy). The assumption that all players stop communicating at the same time seems to us very strong, and not implementable in practice, so we do not make it here. (Dropping this assumption sometimes makes our impossibility results harder to prove; see the proof of TheoremÂ 7 in AppendixÂ A.5 for an example.) Thus, there is essentially only one cheap-talk game extending an underlying game Î“Î“\Gamma,; Î“ctsubscriptÎ“ct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} denotes the cheap-talk extension of Î“Î“\Gamma.

When we consider a deviation by a coalition Kğ¾K, we want to allow the players in Kğ¾K to communicate with each other. If Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} is an extension of an underlying game Î“Î“\Gamma (including Î“Î“\Gamma itself) and KâŠ†Nğ¾ğ‘K\subseteq N, let Î“â€²+Câ€‹Tâ€‹(K)superscriptÎ“â€²ğ¶ğ‘‡ğ¾\Gamma^{\prime}+CT(K) be the extension of Î“Î“\Gamma where the mediator provides private cheap-talk channels for the players in Kğ¾K in addition to whatever communication there is in Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime}. Note that Î“ct+Câ€‹Tâ€‹(K)subscriptÎ“ctğ¶ğ‘‡ğ¾\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}+CT(K) is just Î“ctsubscriptÎ“ct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}; players in Kğ¾K can already talk to each other in Î“ctsubscriptÎ“ct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}}.

2.2 Implementation

Note that a strategy profileâ€”whether it is in the underlying game, or in a game with a mediator extending the underlying game (including a cheap-talk game)â€”induces a mapping from type profiles to distributions over action profiles. If Î“1subscriptÎ“1\Gamma_{1} and Î“2subscriptÎ“2\Gamma_{2} are extension of some underlying game Î“Î“\Gamma, then strategy Ïƒ1subscriptğœ1\sigma_{1} in Î“1subscriptÎ“1\Gamma_{1} implements a strategy Ïƒ2subscriptğœ2\sigma_{2} in Î“2subscriptÎ“2\Gamma_{2} if both Ïƒğœ\sigma and Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime} induce the same function from types to distributions over actions. Note that although our informal discussion in the introduction talked about implementing mediators, the formal definitions (and our theorems) talk about implementing strategies. Our upper bounds show that, under appropriate assumptions, for every (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium Ïƒğœ\sigma in a game Î“1subscriptÎ“1\Gamma_{1} with a mediator, there exists an equilibrium Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime} in the cheap-talk game Î“2subscriptÎ“2\Gamma_{2} corresponding to Î“1subscriptÎ“1\Gamma_{1} that implements Ïƒğœ\sigma; the lower bounds in this paper show that, if these conditions are not met, there exists a game with a mediator and an equilibrium in that game that cannot be implemented in the cheap-talk game. Since our definition of games with a mediator also allow arbitrary communication among the agents, it can also be shown that every equilibrium in a cheap-talk game can be implemented in the mediator game: the players simply ignore the mediator and communicate with each other.

2.3 Solution concepts

We can now define the solution concepts relevant for this paper. In particular, we consider a number of variants of (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t) robustness, and the motivation behind them.

In defining these solution concepts, we need to consider the expected utility of s trategy profile conditional on players having certain types. We abuse notation and continue to use uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} for this, writing for example, uiâ€‹(tK,Ïƒ)subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾ğœu_{i}(t_{K},\sigma) to denote the expected utility to player iğ‘–i if the strategy profile Ïƒğœ\sigma is used, conditional on the players in Kğ¾K having the types tKsubscriptğ‘¡ğ¾t_{K}. Since the strategy Ïƒğœ\sigma here can come from the underlying game or some extension of it, the function uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} is rather badly overloaded. We sometimes include the relevant game as an argument to uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} to emphasize which game the strategy profile Ïƒğœ\sigma is taken from, writing, for example, uiâ€‹(tK,Î“â€²,Ïƒ)subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾superscriptÎ“â€²ğœu_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma^{\prime},\sigma).

kğ‘˜k-resilient equilibrium:

A strategy profile is a Nash equilibrium if no player can gain any advantage by using a different strategy, given that all the other players do not change their strategies. We want to define a notion of kğ‘˜k-resilient equilibrium that generalizes Nash equilibrium, but allows a coalition of up to kğ‘˜k players to change their strategies. One way of capturing this, which goes back to AumannÂ [Aum59], is to require that there be no deviations that result in everyone in a group of size at most kğ‘˜k doing better.

To make this intuition precise, we need some notation. Given a type space ğ’¯ğ’¯{\cal T}, a set Kğ¾K of players, and tâˆˆğ’¯ğ‘¡ğ’¯t\in{\cal T}, let ğ’¯â€‹(tK)={tâ€²:tKâ€²=tK}ğ’¯subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾conditional-setsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾{\cal T}(t_{K})=\{t\,^{\prime}:t\,^{\prime}_{K}=t_{K}\}. If Î“Î“\Gamma is a game over type space ğ’¯ğ’¯{\cal T}, Ïƒğœ\sigma is a strategy profile in Î“Î“\Gamma, and PrPr\Pr is the probability on the type space ğ’¯ğ’¯{\cal T}, let

uiâ€‹(tK,Ïƒ)=âˆ‘tâ€²âˆˆğ’¯â€‹(tK)Prâ¡(tâ€²âˆ£ğ’¯â€‹(tK))â€‹uiâ€‹(tâ€²,Ïƒ).subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ’¯subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾Prconditionalsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ’¯subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğœu_{i}(t_{K},\sigma)=\sum_{t\,^{\prime}\in{\cal T}(t_{K})}\Pr(t\,^{\prime}\mid{\cal T}(t_{K}))u_{i}(t^{\prime},\sigma).

Thus, uiâ€‹(tK,Ïƒ)subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾ğœu_{i}(t_{K},\sigma) is iğ‘–iâ€™s expected payoff if everyone uses strategy Ïƒğœ\sigma and types are restricted to ğ’¯â€‹(tK)ğ’¯subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾{\cal T}(t_{K}).

Definition 1.

Ïƒğœ\sigma is a kğ‘˜k-resilientâ€² equilibrium if, for all KâŠ†Nğ¾ğ‘K\subseteq N and all types tâˆˆğ’¯ğ‘¡ğ’¯t\in{\cal T}, it is not the case that there exists a strategy Ï„ğœ\tau such that uiâ€‹(tK,Ï„K,Ïƒâˆ’K)>uiâ€‹(tK,Ïƒ)subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾subscriptğœğ¾subscriptğœğ¾subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾ğœu_{i}(t_{K},\tau_{K},\sigma_{-K})>u_{i}(t_{K},\sigma) for all iâˆˆKğ‘–ğ¾i\in K.

This is essentially Aummanâ€™sÂ [Aum59] notion of resilience to coalitions, except that we place a bound on the size of coalitions.

As the prime suggests, this will not be exactly the definition we focus on. ADGH consider a stronger notion, which requires that there be no deviation where even one player does better.

Definition 2.

Ïƒğœ\sigma is a strongly kğ‘˜k-resilientâ€² equilibrium if, for all KâŠ†Nğ¾ğ‘K\subseteq N with |K|â‰¤kğ¾ğ‘˜|K|\leq k and all types tâˆˆğ’¯ğ‘¡ğ’¯t\in{\cal T}, it is not the case that there exists a strategy Ï„ğœ\tau such that uiâ€‹(tK,Ï„K,Ïƒâˆ’K)>uiâ€‹(tK,Ïƒ)subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾subscriptğœğ¾subscriptğœğ¾subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾ğœu_{i}(t_{K},\tau_{K},\sigma_{-K})>u_{i}(t_{K},\sigma) for some iâˆˆKğ‘–ğ¾i\in K.

Both of these definitions have a weakness: they implicitly assume that the coalition members cannot communicate with each other beyond agreeing on what strategy to use. While, in general, there are equilibria in the cheap-talk game that are not available in the underlying game (so having more communication can increase the number of possible equilibria), perhaps surprisingly, allowing communication between coalition members can also prevent certain equilibria, as the following example shows.

Example 1.

Consider a game with four players. Players 1 and 2 have a type in {0,1}01\{0,1\}; the type of players 3 and 4 is 0. All tuples of types are equally likely. Players 3 and 4 can each choose an action in the set {0,1,punish,pass}01punishpass\{0,1,{\textsc{punish}},{\textsc{pass}}\}; players 1 and 2 each choose an action in {punish,pass}punishpass\{{\textsc{punish}},{\textsc{pass}}\}. If anyone plays punish,punish{\textsc{punish}}, then everyone gets a payoff of âˆ’11-1. If no one plays punish,punish{\textsc{punish}}, the payoffs are as follows: If player 3 plays pass, then 3 gets a payoff of 1; similarly, if player 4 plays pass, then 4 gets a payoff of 1. If player 3 plays 0 or 1 and this is 1â€™s type, then 3 gets 5; if not, then 3 gets -5; similarly for player 4. Finally, if player 2â€™s type is 00, then player 1 and 2â€™s payoffs are the same as player 333â€™s payoffs; similarly, if player 2 has a 1, then 1 and 2â€™s payoffs are the same as 4â€™s payoffs. It is easy to see that everyone playing pass is a 3-resilientâ€² equilibrium in the underlying game and it is also an equilibrium in the game with a mediator, if the players cannot communicate. However, if players can communicate for one round, then players 1, 2, and 3 can do better if player 1 sends player 3 his type, and player 3 plays it. This guarantees player 3 a payoff of 5, while players 1 and 2 get an expected payoff of 2.52.52.5.

Now suppose that we consider a variant of this game, where the actions are the same and the payoffs for players 3 and 4 are the same, but the payoffs for players 1 and 2 are modified as follows. If player 2â€™s type is 00, then if no one plays punish, player 1 and 2â€™s payoffs are the same as player 333â€™s payoffs if player 4 plays pass; if player 4 plays 0 or 1, then their payoff is âˆ’55-5. Similarly, if player 2â€™s type is 1, then player 1 and 2â€™s payoffs are the same player 444â€™s payoffs if player 3 plays pass; if player 3 plays 0 or 1, then their payoff is âˆ’55-5. It is easy to show that everyone playing pass is still 3-resilientâ€² if we allow only one round of communication. But with two rounds of communication, everyone playing pass is no longer 3-resilientâ€²: players 1, 2, and 3 can do better if player 2 sends player 1 his type, player 1 sends player 3 his type if player 2â€™s type is 0 (and sends nothing otherwise), and player 3 plays player 1â€™s type if player 1 sends it. âŠ“square-intersection\sqcapâŠ”square-union\sqcup

Since it seems reasonable to assume that coalition members will communicate, it seems unreasonable to call everyone playing pass 3-resilient if some communication among coalition members can destroy that equilibrium. More generally, we clearly cannot hope to implement a kğ‘˜k-resilient equilibrium in the mediator game using cheap talk if the equilibrium does not survive once we allow communication among the coalition members. This motivates the following definition.

Definition 3.

Ïƒğœ\sigma is a (strongly) kğ‘˜k-resilient equilibrium in a game Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} if, for all KâŠ†Nğ¾ğ‘K\subseteq N with |K|â‰¤kğ¾ğ‘˜|K|\leq k and all types tâˆˆğ’¯ğ‘¡ğ’¯t\in{\cal T}, it is not the case that there exists a strategy Ï„ğœ\tau such that uiâ€‹(tK,Î“â€²+Câ€‹Tâ€‹(K),Ï„K,Ïƒâˆ’K)>uiâ€‹(tK,Î“â€²,Ïƒ)subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾superscriptÎ“â€²ğ¶ğ‘‡ğ¾subscriptğœğ¾subscriptğœğ¾subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾superscriptÎ“â€²ğœu_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma^{\prime}+CT(K),\tau_{K},\sigma_{-K})>u_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma^{\prime},\sigma) for some iâˆˆKğ‘–ğ¾i\in K.

This definition makes precise the intuition that players in the coalition are allowed arbitrary communication among themselves.

Note that Nash equilibrium is equivalent to both 1-resilience and strong 1-resilience; however, the notions differ for k>1ğ‘˜1k>1. It seems reasonable in many applications to bound the size of coalitions; it is hard to coordinate a large coalition! Of course, the appropriate bound on the size of the coalition may well depend on the utilities involved. Our interest in strong kğ‘˜k-resilience was motivated by wanting to allow situations where one player effectively controls the coalition. This can happen in practice in a network if one player can â€œhijackâ€ a number of nodes in the network. It could also happen if one player can threaten others, or does so much better as a result of the deviation that he persuades other players to go along, perhaps by the promise of side payments. While it can be argued that, if there are side payments or threats, they should be modeled in the utilities of the game, it is sometimes more convenient to work directly with strong resilience. In this paper we consider both resilience and strong resilience, since the results on implementation obtained using the different notions are incomparable. Just because a strongly resilient strategy in a game with a mediator can be implemented by a strongly resilient strategy in a cheap-talk game, it does not follow that a resilient strategy with a mediator can be implemented by a resilient strategy in a cheap-talk game, or vice versa. However, as we show, we get the same lower bounds for both resilience and strong resilience: in our lower bounds, we give games with mediators with a strongly kğ‘˜k-resilient equilibrium Ïƒğœ\sigma and show that there does not exist a cheap-talk game and a strategy that Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime} that implements Ïƒğœ\sigma and is kğ‘˜k-resilient. Similarly, we can show that we get the same upper bounds with both kğ‘˜k-resilience and strong kğ‘˜k-resilience.

Other notions of resilience to coalitions have been defined in the literature. For example, Bernheim, Peleg, and Whinston [BPW89] define a notion of coalition-proof Nash equilibrium that, roughly speaking, attempts to capture the intuition that Ïƒğœ\sigma is a coalition-proof equilibrium if there is no deviation that allows all players to do better. However, they argue that this is too strong a requirement, in that some deviations are not viable: they are not immune from further deviations. Thus, they give a rather complicated definition that tries to capture the intuition of a deviation that is immune from further deviations. This work is extended by Moreno and Wooders [MW96] to allow correlated strategies. Although it is beyond the scope of this paper to go through the definitions, it is easy to see that our impossibility results apply to them, because of the particular structure of the games we consider.

For some of our results we will be interested in strategies that give â€œalmostâ€ kğ‘˜k-resilience, in the sense that no player in a coalition can do more than Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon better by deviating, for some small Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon.

Definition 4.

If Ïµâ‰¥0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon\geq 0, then Ïƒğœ\sigma is an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“kğ‘˜k-resilient equilibrium in a game Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma^{\prime} if, for all KâŠ†Nğ¾ğ‘K\subseteq N with |K|â‰¤kğ¾ğ‘˜|K|\leq k and all types tâˆˆğ’¯ğ‘¡ğ’¯t\in{\cal T}, it is not the case that there exists a strategy Ï„ğœ\tau such that uiâ€‹(tK,Î“â€²+Câ€‹Tâ€‹(K),Ï„K,Ïƒâˆ’K)>uiâ€‹(tK,Î“â€²,Ïƒ)+Ïµsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾superscriptÎ“â€²ğ¶ğ‘‡ğ¾subscriptğœğ¾subscriptğœğ¾subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ¾superscriptÎ“â€²ğœitalic-Ïµu_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma^{\prime}+CT(K),\tau_{K},\sigma_{-K})>u_{i}(t_{K},\Gamma^{\prime},\sigma)+\epsilon for all iâˆˆKğ‘–ğ¾i\in K.

Clearly if Ïµ=0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon=0, then an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“kğ‘˜k-resilient equilibrium is a kğ‘˜k-resilient equilibrium.

(k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium:

We now define the main solution concept used in this paper: (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium. The kğ‘˜k indicates the size of coalition we are willing to tolerate, and the tğ‘¡t indicates the number of players with unknown utilities. These tğ‘¡t players are analogues of faulty players or adversaries in the distributed computing literature, but we can think of them as being perfectly rational. Since we do not know what actions these tğ‘¡t players will perform, nor do we know their identities, we are interested in strategies for which the payoffs of the remaining players are immune to what the tğ‘¡t players do.

Intuitively, Ïƒğœ\sigma is tğ‘¡t-immune if there is nothing that players in a set Tğ‘‡T of size at most tğ‘¡t can do to give the remaining players a worse payoff, even if the players in Tğ‘‡T can communicate.

Our notion of (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robustness requires both tğ‘¡t-immunity and kğ‘˜k-resilience. In fact, it requires kğ‘˜k-resilience no matter what up to tğ‘¡t players do. That is, we require that no matter what tğ‘¡t players do, no subset of size at most kğ‘˜k can all do better by deviating, even with the help of the tğ‘¡t players, and even if all k+tğ‘˜ğ‘¡k+t players share their type information.

We can define a strongly (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium by analogy to the definition strongly kğ‘˜k-resilient equilibrium: we simply change â€œfor all iâˆˆKğ‘–ğ¾i\in Kâ€ in the definition of (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium to â€œfor some iâˆˆKğ‘–ğ¾i\in Kâ€. Note that a (1,0)10(1,0)-robust equilibrium is just a Nash equilibrium, and an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“(1,0)10(1,0)-robust equilibrium is what has been called an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-Nash equilibrium in the literature. A (strongly) (k,0)ğ‘˜0(k,0)-robust equilibrium is just a (strongly) kğ‘˜k-resilient equilibrium. The notion (0,t)0ğ‘¡(0,t)-robustness is somewhat in the spirit of Eliazâ€™sÂ [Eli02] notion of tğ‘¡t fault-tolerant implementation. In this paper, we are interested in the question of when a (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium Ïƒğœ\sigma in a game Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} with a mediator extending an underlying game Î“Î“\Gamma can be implemented by an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“(k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime} in the cheap-talk extension Î“ctsubscriptÎ“ct\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} of Î“Î“\Gamma. (We sometimes say that (Î“ct,Ïƒâ€²)subscriptÎ“ctsuperscriptğœâ€²(\Gamma_{\!\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}},\sigma^{\prime}) is an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“(k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust implementation of (Î“d,Ïƒ)subscriptÎ“ğ‘‘ğœ(\Gamma_{d},\sigma) if we wish to emphasize the games.)

3 The Possibility Results

All of our possibility results have the flavor â€œif there is a (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium in a game with a mediator, then (under the appropriate assumptions) we can implement this equilibrium using cheap talk.â€ To state the results carefully, we must define the notions of a punishment strategy and a utility variant.

Definition 7.

If Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} is an extension of an underlying game Î“Î“\Gamma with a mediator dğ‘‘d, a strategy profile ÏğœŒ\rho in Î“Î“\Gamma is a kğ‘˜k-punishment strategy with respect to a strategy profile Ïƒğœ\sigma in Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} if for all subsets KâŠ†Nğ¾ğ‘K\subseteq N with |K|â‰¤kğ¾ğ‘˜|K|\leq k, all strategies Ï•italic-Ï•\phi in Î“+Câ€‹Tâ€‹(K)Î“ğ¶ğ‘‡ğ¾\Gamma+CT(K), all types tKâˆˆTKsubscriptğ‘¡ğ¾subscriptğ‘‡ğ¾t_{K}\in T_{K}, and all players iâˆˆKğ‘–ğ¾i\in K:

The notion of utility variant is used to make precise that certain results do not depend on knowing the playersâ€™ utilities; they hold independently of playersâ€™ utilities in the game. A game Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma\,^{\prime} is a utility variant of a game Î“Î“\Gamma if Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma\,^{\prime} and Î“Î“\Gamma have the same game tree, but the utilities of the players may be different in Î“Î“\Gamma and Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma\,^{\prime}. Note that if Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma\,^{\prime} is a utility variant of Î“Î“\Gamma, then Î“Î“\Gamma and Î“â€²superscriptÎ“â€²\Gamma\,^{\prime} have the same set of strategies. We use the notation Î“â€‹(u)Î“ğ‘¢\Gamma(u) if we want to emphasize that uğ‘¢u is the utility function in game Î“Î“\Gamma. We then take Î“â€‹(uâ€²)Î“superscriptğ‘¢â€²\Gamma(u\hskip 1.42262pt^{\prime}) to be the utility variant of Î“Î“\Gamma with utility functions uâ€²superscriptğ‘¢â€²u\hskip 1.42262pt^{\prime}.

We say that broadcast can be simulated, if for all Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0, broadcast channels can be implemented with probability 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta. Broadcast can be simulated if, for example, there are broadcast channels; or if there is a trusted preprocessing phase where players may broadcast and assuming cryptography; or if unconditional pseudo-signatures are established [PW96].

In the theorem, we take â€œassuming cryptographyâ€ to be a shorthand for the assumption that oblivious transfer [Rab, EGL85] can be implemented with probability 1âˆ’Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1-\epsilon for any desired Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0. It is known that this assumption holds if enhanced trapdoor permutations exist, players are computationally bounded, and the mediator can be described by a polynomial-size circuit [Gol04].

Note that in part (a) we say â€œthe running timeâ€, while in the other parts we say â€œthe expected running timeâ€. Although all the strategies used are behavior strategies (and thus use randomization), in part (a), the running time is bounded, independent of the randomization. In the remaining parts, we cannot put an a priori bound on the running time; it depends on the random choices. As our lower bounds show, this must be the case.

We briefly comment on the differences between TheoremÂ 1 and the corresponding Theorem 4 of ADGH. In ADGH, we were interested in finding strategies that were not only (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust, but also survived iterated deletion of weakly dominated strategies. Here, to simplify the exposition, we just focus on (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibria. For part (a), in ADGH, a behavioral strategy was used that had no upper bound on running time. This was done in order to obtain a strategy that survived iterated deletion. However, it is observed in ADGH that, without this concern, a strategy with a known upper bound can be used. As we observed in the introduction, part (a), as stated, actually follows from known results in multiparty computation [BGW88, CCD88]. Part (b) here is the same as in ADGH. In part (c), we assume here the ability to simulate broadcast; ADGH assumes cryptography. As we have observed, in the presence of cryptography, we can simulate broadcast, so the assumption here is weaker. In any case, as observed in the introduction, part (c) follows from known results [RB89]. Parts (d) and (e) are new, and will be proved in [ADGH07]. The proof uses ideas from [GMW87] on multiparty computation. For part (d), where there is no punishment strategy, ideas from [EGL85] on getting Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-fair protocols are also required. (An Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-fair protocols is one where if one player knows the mediatorâ€™s value with probability pğ‘p, then other players know it with probability at least pâˆ’Ïµğ‘italic-Ïµp-\epsilon.) Our proof of part (e) shows that if n>k+3â€‹tğ‘›ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n>k+3t, then we can essentially set up a PKI on the fly. These results strengthen Theorem 4(d) in ADGH, where punishment was required and nğ‘›n was required to be greater than k+2â€‹tğ‘˜2ğ‘¡k+2t.

4 The Impossibility Results

No bounded implementations

We prove that it is impossible to get an implementation with bounded running time in general if 2â€‹k+3â€‹t<nâ‰¤3â€‹k+3â€‹t2ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡ğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡2k+3t<n\leq 3k+3t. This is true even if there is a punishment strategy. This result is optimal. If 3â€‹k+3â€‹t<n3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡ğ‘›3k+3t<n, then there does exist a bounded implementation; if 2â€‹k+3â€‹t<nâ‰¤3â€‹k+3â€‹t2ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡ğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡2k+3t<n\leq 3k+3t there exists an unbounded implementation that has constant expected running time.

Theorem 2.

If 2â€‹k+3â€‹t<nâ‰¤3â€‹k+3â€‹t2ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡ğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡2k+3t<n\leq 3k+3t, there is a game Î“Î“\Gamma and a strong (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium Ïƒğœ\sigma of a game Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dğ‘‘d that extends Î“Î“\Gamma such that there exists a (k+t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to Ïƒğœ\sigma for which there do not exist a natural number cğ‘c and a strategy Ïƒctsubscriptğœct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the cheap talk game extending Î“Î“\Gamma such that the running time of Ïƒctsubscriptğœct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} on the equilibrium path is at most cğ‘c and Ïƒctsubscriptğœct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} is a (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust implementation of Ïƒğœ\sigma.

Let Ïƒisubscriptğœğ‘–\sigma_{i} be the strategy where player iğ‘–i truthfully tells the mediator his type and follows the mediatorâ€™s recommendation. Byzantine Agreement and Game Theory

In [ADGH06] it is shown that if n>3â€‹k+3â€‹tğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n>3k+3t, we can implement a mediator in a way that does not depend on utilities and does not need a punishment strategy. Using novel connections to randomized Byzantine agreement lower bounds, we show that neither of these properties hold in general if nâ‰¤3â€‹k+3â€‹tğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n\leq 3k+3t.

We start by showing that we cannot handle all utilities variants if nâ‰¤3â€‹k+3â€‹tğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n\leq 3k+3t. Our proof exposes a new connection between utility variants and the problem of Weak Byzantine AgreementÂ [Lam83]. LamportÂ [Lam83] showed that there is no deterministic protocol with bounded running time for weak Byzantine agreement if tâ‰¥n/3ğ‘¡ğ‘›3t\geq n/3. We prove a stronger lower bound for any randomized protocol that only assumes that the running time has finite expectation.

Proposition 1.

If maxâ¡{2,k+t}<nâ‰¤3â€‹k+3â€‹t2ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡\max\{2,k+t\}<n\leq 3k+3t, all 2nsuperscript2ğ‘›2^{n} input values are equally likely, and Pğ‘ƒP is a (possibly randomized) protocol with finite expected running time (that is, for all protocols Pâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²â€²P^{\prime\prime} and sets |T|â‰¤k+tğ‘‡ğ‘˜ğ‘¡|T|\leq k+t, the expected running time of processes PNâˆ’Tsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘‡P_{N-T} given (PNâˆ’T,PTâ€²â€²)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²â€²ğ‘‡(P_{N-T},P^{\prime\prime}_{T}) is finite), then there exists a protocol Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime} and a set Tğ‘‡T of players with |T|â‰¤k+tğ‘‡ğ‘˜ğ‘¡|T|\leq k+t such that an execution of (PNâˆ’T,PTâ€²)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²ğ‘‡(P_{N-T},P^{\prime}_{T}) is unsuccessful for the weak Byzantine agreement problem with nonzero probability.

Proof.

See AppendixÂ A.1. âˆ

The idea of our impossibility result is to construct a game that captures weak Byzantine agreement. The challenge in the proof is that, while in the Byzantine agreement problem, nature chooses which processes are faulty, in the game, the players decide whether or not to behave in a faulty way. Thus, we must set up the incentives so that players gain by choosing to be faulty iff Byzantine agreement cannot be attained, while ensuring that a (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust cheap-talk implementation of the mediatorâ€™s strategy in the game will solve Byzantine agreement.

Tight bounds on running time

5 Conclusions

We have provided conditions under which a (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium with a mediator can be implemented using cheap talk, and proved essentially matching lower bounds. There are still a few gaps in our theorems, as well as other related issues to explore. We list some of them here.

  • â€¢

    In TheoremÂ 1(c), we get only an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-implementation for some Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0. Can we take Ïµ=0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon=0 here?

  • â€¢

    We require that the cheap-talk implementation be only a Nash equilibrium. But when we use a punishment strategy, this may require a player to do something that results in him being much worse off (although in equilibrium this will never occur, since if everyone follows the recommended strategy, there will never be a need for punishment). It may be more reasonable to require that the cheap-talk implementation be a sequential equilibrium [KW82] where, intuitively, a player is making a best response even off the equilibrium path. To ensure that the cheap-talk strategy is a sequential equilibrium, Ben-Porath [Ben03] requires that the punishment strategy itself be a Nash equilibrium. We believe for our results where a punishment strategy is not required, the cheap-talk strategy is in fact a sequential equilibrium and, in the cases where a punishment strategy is required, if we assume that the punishment strategy is a Nash equilibrium, then the cheap-talk strategy will be a sequential equilibrium. However, we have not checked this carefully. It would also be interesting to consider the extent to which the cheap-talk strategy satisfies other refinements of Nash equilibrium, such as perfect equilibrium [Sel75].

  • â€¢

    Our focus in this paper has been the synchronous case. We are currently exploring the asynchronous case. While we had originally assumed that implementation would not be possible in the asynchronous case, it now seems that many of the ideas of our possibility results carry over to the asynchronous case. However, a number of new issues arise. In particular, we need to be careful in dealing with uncertainty. The traditional assumption in game theory is to quantify all uncertainty probabilistically. But with asynchrony, part of the uncertainty involves, how long it will take a message to arrive and when agents will be scheduled to move. (In general, in an asynchronous setting, one player can make many moves before a second agent makes a single move.) It is far from clear what an appropriate distribution would be to characterize this uncertainty. Thus, the tradition in distributed computing has been to assume that an adversary decides message delivery time and when agents are scheduled. The results in the asynchronous case depend on how we deal with the uncertainty, which in turn affects the notion of equilibrium.

  • â€¢

    We have assumed that in the cheap-talk game, every player can talk directly to every other player. It would be interesting to examine what happens if there is a communication network which characterizes which players a given player can talk to directly.

  • â€¢

    In the definition of tğ‘¡t-immunity and (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robustness, we have allowed the players in Tğ‘‡T to use arbitrary strategies. In practice, we may be interested only in restricting each player iğ‘–i in Tğ‘‡T to using a strategy in some predetermined set Siâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–â€²S_{i}^{\prime}.

We hope to return to all these issues in future work.

Appendix

Appendix A Proofs

This section includes the proofs for all results stated in the main text. We repeat the statement of the results for the readersâ€™ convenience.

A.1 Proof of TheoremÂ 3

In the weak Byzantine agreement problem, there are nğ‘›n processes, up to tğ‘¡t of which may be faulty (â€œByzantineâ€). Each process has some initial value, either 00 or 111. Some processes (chosen by nature) are faulty; their â€œintentionâ€ is to try to prevent agreement among the remaining processes. Each non-Byzantine process must decide 00 or 111. An execution of a protocol Pğ‘ƒP is successful for weak Byzantine agreement if the following two conditions hold:

  1. I.

    (Agreement:) All the non-Byzantine processes decide on the same value in {0,1}01\{0,1\}.

  2. II.

    (Weak Nontriviality:) If all processes are non-Byzantine and all processes have the same initial value iğ‘–i, then all the processes must decide iğ‘–i.

  • Â Â Â PropositionÂ Â 1.

    If maxâ¡{2,k+t}<nâ‰¤3â€‹k+3â€‹t2ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡\max\{2,k+t\}<n\leq 3k+3t, all 2nsuperscript2ğ‘›2^{n} input values are equally likely, and Pğ‘ƒP is a (possibly randomized) protocol with finite expected running time, then there exists a protocol Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime} and a set Tğ‘‡T of players with |T|â‰¤k+tğ‘‡ğ‘˜ğ‘¡|T|\leq k+t such that an execution of (PNâˆ’T,PTâ€²)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²ğ‘‡(P_{N-T},P^{\prime}_{T}) is unsuccessful for the weak Byzantine agreement problem with nonzero probability.

Proof.

The proof is based on the argument of [FLM86]. A.2 Proof of TheoremÂ 4

    If 2â€‹k+2â€‹t<nâ‰¤3â€‹k+3â€‹t2ğ‘˜2ğ‘¡ğ‘›3ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡2k+2t<n\leq 3k+3t, then there exists a game Î“Î“\Gamma, an Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0, and a strong (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium Ïƒğœ\sigma of a game Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dğ‘‘d that extends Î“Î“\Gamma, for which there does not exist a strategy Ïƒctsubscriptğœct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the CT game that extends Î“Î“\Gamma such that Ïƒctsubscriptğœct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} is an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“(k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust implementation of Ïƒğœ\sigma.

      all players in Rğ‘…R either commonly output 0 or commonly output 1; and

A.4 Proof of TheoremÂ 6

  • Â Â Â TheoremÂ Â 6.

    If 2â€‹k+2â€‹t<nâ‰¤2â€‹k+3â€‹t2ğ‘˜2ğ‘¡ğ‘›2ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡2k+2t<n\leq 2k+3t and tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1, there exists a game Î“Î“\Gamma, an Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0, a strong (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium Ïƒğœ\sigma of a game Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dğ‘‘d that extends Î“Î“\Gamma, and a (k+t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k+t)-punishment strategy with respect to Ïƒğœ\sigma, such that there does not exist a strategy Ïƒctsubscriptğœct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the CT extension of Î“Î“\Gamma which is an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“(k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust implementation of Ïƒğœ\sigma.

The proof uses a reduction to a generalization of the Byzantine agreement problem called the (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-Detect/AgreeÂ problem, which, as we said, is closely related to the problem of broadcast with extended consistency introduced by FitziÂ et al.Â [FHHW03]. We have two parameters, kğ‘˜k and tğ‘¡t. Each process has some initial value, either 00 or 111. There are at most k+tğ‘˜ğ‘¡k+t Byzantine processes. Each non-Byzantine process must decide 0,1,010,1, or detect. An execution is successful for Detect/Agree if the following three conditions all hold (the first two of which are slight variants of the corresponding conditions in weak Byzantine agreement):

  1. I.

    (Agreement:) If there are tğ‘¡t or fewer Byzantine processes, then all non-Byzantine processes decide on the same value, and it is a value in {0,1}01\{0,1\}.

  2. II.

    (Nontriviality:) If all non-Byzantine processes have the same initial value vğ‘£v and no non-Byzantine process decides detect, then all the non-Byzantine processes must decide vğ‘£v.

  3. III.

    (Detection validity:) If there are more than tğ‘¡t Byzantine processes, then either all the non-Byzantine processes decide detect, or all non-Byzantine processes decide on the same value in {0,1}01\{0,1\}.

Note that if k=0ğ‘˜0k=0, then clause III is vacuous, so the (0,t)0ğ‘¡(0,t)-Detect/AgreeÂ problem is equivalent to Byzantine agreement with tğ‘¡t faulty processes [LSP82]. Note that the non-triviality condition for Byzantine agreement requires all processes to decide vğ‘£v if they all had initial value vğ‘£v, even if there are some faulty processes. Thus, it is a more stringent requirement than the weak nontriviality condition of weak Byzantine agreement.

The following argument, from which it follows that there does not exist a protocol for the (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-Detect/AgreeÂ problem if nâ‰¤2â€‹k+3â€‹tğ‘›2ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡n\leq 2k+3t, is based on a variant of the argument used for PropositionÂ 1. If TâŠ†Nğ‘‡ğ‘T\subseteq N, let 1â†’Tâ€‹0â†’Nâˆ’Tsubscriptâ†’1ğ‘‡subscriptâ†’0ğ‘ğ‘‡\vec{1}_{T}\vec{0}_{N-T} denote the input vector where the players in Tğ‘‡T get an input of 1 and the players in Nâˆ’Tğ‘ğ‘‡N-T get an input of 0.

A.5 Proof of TheoremÂ 7

To prove TheoremÂ 7, we start with the case that n=2ğ‘›2n=2, k=1ğ‘˜1k=1, and t=0ğ‘¡0t=0. The ideas for this proof actually go back to Shamir, Rivest, and Adleman [SRA81]; a similar result is also proved by Heller [Hel05]. However, these earlier proofs assume that in the cheap-talk protocol, the players first exchange messages and then, after the message exchange, make their decision (perhaps using some randomization). That is, they are implicitly assuming that when the cheap-talk phase of the strategy has ended, it is common knowledge that it has ended (although when it ends may depend on some random choices). While this is a reasonable assumption if we have a bounded cheap-talk protocol, our possibility results involve cheap-talk games with no a priori upper bound on running time. We do not want to assume that the players receive a signal of some sort to indicate that the message exchange portion of the cheap-talk has ended. Our lower bound proof does not make this assumption. We can, of course, find a round such bğ‘b that with high probability. This solves part of the problem. However, the earlier proofs also took advantage of the fact that players decide simultaneously, after the cheap-talk phase ends. Since we do not make this assumption, our proof requires somewhat more delicate techniques than the proofs in the earlier papers.

Proposition 6.

If n=2ğ‘›2n=2, then there exist a game Î“Î“\Gamma, Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0, a mediator game Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} extending Î“Î“\Gamma, a Nash equilibrium Ïƒğœ\sigma of Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d}, and a punishment strategy ÏğœŒ\rho with respect to Ïƒğœ\sigma such that there is no strategy Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime} that is an Ïµâ€“â€‹(1,0)Ïµâ€“10\mbox{$\epsilon$--}(1,0)-robust implementation of Ïƒğœ\sigma.

A.6 Proof of TheoremÂ 8

  • Â Â Â TheoremÂ Â 8.

    If maxâ¡(2,k+t)<nâ‰¤k+3â€‹t2ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡\max(2,k+t)<n\leq k+3t, then there is a game Î“Î“\Gamma, a strong (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust equilibrium Ïƒğœ\sigma of a game Î“dsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‘\Gamma_{d} with a mediator dğ‘‘d that extends Î“Î“\Gamma for which there does not exist a strategy Ïƒctsubscriptğœct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} in the CT game that extends Î“Î“\Gamma such that Ïƒctsubscriptğœct\sigma_{\mbox{\footnotesize\sc ct}} is an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€“(k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-robust implementation of Ïƒğœ\sigma even if players are computationally bounded and we assume cryptography.

Proof.

We consider a relaxation of Byzantine agreement that we call the (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-partial broadcast problem. There are nğ‘›n processes and process 111 is designated as leader. The leader has an initial value 0 or 1. Each process must decide on a value in {0,1,pass}01pass\{0,1,{\textsc{pass}}\}. An execution of a protocol Pğ‘ƒP is successful for (k,t)ğ‘˜ğ‘¡(k,t)-partial broadcast if the following two conditions hold:

  1. I.

    (Agreement): If there are tğ‘¡t or fewer Byzantine processes and the leader is non-Byzantine then all non-Byzantine processes decide on the leaderâ€™s value.

  2. II.

    (No disagreement): If there are k+tğ‘˜ğ‘¡k+t or fewer Byzantine processes, then there do not exist two non-Byzantine processes such that one decides 0 and the other decides 1.

Note that if the leader is faulty, it is acceptable that some non-Byzantine processes decide on a common value vâˆˆ{0,1}ğ‘£01v\in\{0,1\} and all other non-Byzantine processes decide pass. Observe that the (0,t)0ğ‘¡(0,t)-partial broadcast problem is a relaxation of the well-known Byzantine generals problem [LSP82]. We provide probabilistic lower bounds for this problem, which also imply known probabilistic lower bounds for the Byzantine generals problem.

Proposition 7.

For the general argument, we do the proof of part (a) here; the modifications needed to deal with part (b) are straightforward. In the mediator game, each player is supposed to send the mediator his type (share, signatures, and verifications). The mediator checks that all the shares sent pass the checks. Note that each share can be subjected to nğ‘›n checks, one for each player. A share is reliable if it passes at least nâˆ’tğ‘›ğ‘¡n-t checks. If so, the mediator sends the secret to all the players; if not, the mediator sends detect to all the players.
